Award.AwardTitle: Design for a Megaton-Scale Water Cerenkov Detector for the Deep Underground Science and Engineering Lab
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal, from the University of California at Davis, requests funds for a three year planning effort that will culminate in a Preliminary Design for a megaton scale water Cherenkov detector at DUSEL and a Near Detector at Fermilab. The last decade has been one of rapid progress in the field of neutrino physics and astrophysics. Neutrino flavor oscillations have been discovered, implying that the mass of the neutrino is non zero and that the mass and flavor states are mixed. Several precision measurements of the mixing parameters have been made or are now in progress, and a new generation of experiments designed to measure the unknown mixing angle theta-13 are now under construction. The neutrino spectrum from the sun has been measured for 8B and 7Be neutrinos, and radiochemical experiments have measured the integral solar neutrino flux including the pp reaction. To build upon these discoveries, the Particle Physics Project Prioritization Panel (P5) in 2007-08. in a report endorsed by HEPAP, called for a new neutrino initiative in the U.S. as part of a three pronged program in particle physics over the next decade. The flagship of this initiative would be an intense neutrino beam from Fermilab to a large detector at the DUSEL in South Dakota.

This award, through a Cooperative Agreement with the University of California at Davis, would fund much of the university-based component of this effort, although the proposal also describes the entire planning effort including tasks that will be done at collaborating US national labs and or collaborating European institutions. Major tasks to be funded by this proposal are:

Preliminary design for a Containment Vessel and associated infrastructure. This includes funding for establishment of a liaison group of physics and engineers to coordinate this planning effort with the existing DUSEL S3 organization.

Development of detector simulations and analysis tools to address crucial design questions on detector optimization, including photomultiplier coverage and pixelization, veto requirements, calibration specifications, and energy threshold and resolution.

Testing and characterization of photomultiplier tubes, including new models with high QE. This will include investigation of the use of light concentrators and waveshifter plates.

Preliminary design of a water system, including support for a practical design of a system that could handle loading the water with gadolinium to allow detection of neutrons.

Preliminary design for electronics, high voltage, and DAQ systems.

The scientific goals of the proposed facility are broad, cutting across several disciplines, including stellar astrophysics, solar physics, and geotechnical and electrical engineering. This award will fund four international workshops on the science goals and engineering design of the detector, and will also support formulation of an Education and Outreach Plan in collaboration with the DUSEL S3 organization through LBL

Neutrino physics is one of the broadest and most active areas in science today. This is due to the fact that, while neutrinos are one of the most mysterious of subatomic particles, they are literally everywhere. Neutrinos are emitted from the core of the sun and from the crust of the earth. They are manufactured in the Earth's upper atmosphere and just below the surface of seconds-old neutron stars. Ultra-high energy neutrinos have recently been seen to arrive at Earth from outside our galaxy and they have been detected coming from nuclear reactors by detectors hundereds of kilometers distant. While we do not sense them directlly, there are in fact about a billion neutrinos for every atom in our universe. We know this, as their imprint can clearly be seen in the distorted distribution of radio waves left over from the Big Bang. 

Despite this, we know very little about neutrinos. They do not seem to easily "fit in" with what has become known as the "Standard Model" of particle physics. One of the attached figures shows the masses of all the fundamental fermions on a logarithmic scale. If fundamental particles are supposed to get their masses from interactions with the Higgs particle, then why are the neutrinos so light? To get an idea of scale, if a signle electron weighed as much as an aircraft carrier, a single neutrino (even the heavist kind) would only weight about as much as a bicycle. There is speculation as to whether the neutrino even interacts with the Higgs particle at all.

In additon to the mass issue, There are many other unanswered fundamental questions: Why are the families profoundly "mixed up", causing neutrino types to oscillate back and forth? Do neutrinos have the same matter/anti-matter symmenty as "normal" particles - or do they violate so-called "CP symmetry", which would allow them to shift the balance of matter and anti-matter in the Big Bang in favor of universe we see today. 

The purpose of this project was to begin the design of a large water Cherenkov detector to study neutrinos from distant accelerators, the sun, the earth, and supernovae. Such a detector would also be capable of detecting rare forms of radioactivity predicted but as of yet never seen: proton decay and neutrinoless double beta decay.

The attached figures show the design of a 200 kiloton detector planned for deployment in the Sanford Underground Research Facility (SURF). In partnership with the Department of Energy, a full Conceptual Design Report was produced detailing the cavern construction, detector fabrication, and science sensitivity of the facility. This design was one of two options for the Long Baseline Neutrino Experiment (LBNE) and was the one favored by the science community in a vote. Unfortunately, SInce NSF declined to fund the underground facility, the decision on detector technology was made by the Fermilab Director who chose a liquid argon TPC design instead.This type of detector design is strongly oriented towards accelerator-based neutrino physics and has much narrower applicability outside that application.

Nevertheless, the LBNE CDR has had an impact on other proposed projects such as Hyper-Kamiokande in Japan (see attached figure). While this was initially planned as a two-horizontal tank design, recent studies have show that a more LBNE-like design might have significant advantages.
